Primary Offense: Medicare Parts C and D Enforcement Action

Description: Excellus Bluecross Blueshield agreed to pay $3.1 million in refunds to resolve allegations that it caused plan members to overpay healthcare providers as a result of improper accounting of deductibles.

To resolve a case involving allegations of unfair health insurance reimbursement rates, Excellus agreed to pay $775,000 to a qualified nonprofit organization that would establish a new, independent database to help determine fair out-of-network reimbursement rates for consumers throughout the United States.

The New York Attorney announced agreements with six health maintenance organizations that would empower consumers to challenge denials of coverage. The HMOs also agreed to pay a total of $1 million to the state AG's office to cover the cost of the investigation. The announcement did not specify how that cost would be divided among the six plans. Here we assume it was split equally.

New York State authorities ordered 11 insurance companies to refund a total of $114.5 million to holders of policies that covered 573,748 people who were overcharged for health insurance premiums in 2010.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined Excellus Health Plan Inc. $995,000 for improperly denying 166 emergency room claims and for failing to explain coverage to consumers in 337,689 instances.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Four insurers agreed to pay a total of $2.2 million in restitution to 3,475 New York seniors from across the state for overcharging them on Medicare supplemental insurance policies in violation of New York law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Excellus Health Plans, Inc. was fined $1 million by the Department of Financial Services for violations of New York insurance law after an investigation found that the insurer wrongly denied contraceptive coverage due to internal system and process errors, failed to promptly pay or deny claims, and failed to acknowledge or resolve consumer grievances within time frames required by law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
New York Department of Financial Services
